title: 115_s1400
content: The Act may be cited as the "Safeguard Tribal Objects of Patrimony Act of 2017" and provides enhanced protections for Native American cultural heritage. The "Safeguard Tribal Objects of Patrimony Act of 2017" enhances penalties for illegal exportation of Native American cultural heritage, increasing the penalty from 5 years to 10 years. It also defines key terms like archaeological resource, cultural item, and Native American. The term 'Native American' is defined as per the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act. It is illegal to knowingly export Native American cultural items, archaeological resources, or objects of antiquity obtained in violation of specific acts. Violators of this prohibition will face penalties. The penalties for violating the prohibition on exporting Native American cultural items include fines and imprisonment for up to 10 years for repeat offenders. The Attorney General and Secretary of Homeland Security will establish necessary regulations, and a technical amendment will be made to the relevant legal code. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, key definitions include "Indian tribe," "Native American," "Native Hawaiian organization," "Secretary," and "tangible cultural heritage." The curr_chunk refers to culturally, historically, or archaeologically significant objects affiliated with a Native American culture. The curr_chunk discusses the voluntary return of tangible cultural heritage, specifically objects affiliated with a Native American culture. The United States encourages the voluntary return of tangible cultural heritage to Indian tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations. Liaisons are designated to facilitate this process, and trainings are held for relevant parties. The Secretary refers individuals and organizations to tribes or organizations with cultural affiliations to the heritage. The Secretary compiles a list of representatives from Indian tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations for referral purposes. Consultation with these groups possessing unique expertise in cultural heritage is required before making referrals. Third-party experts from academic institutions and museums may be utilized to determine the appropriate tribe or organization for referral. The Secretary compiles a list of representatives from Indian tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations for referral purposes, consulting with groups possessing expertise in cultural heritage. Third-party experts may be used to determine the appropriate tribe or organization for referral. Additionally, a Tribal Working Group is established. The Secretary convenes a tribal working group with representatives of Indian tribes and Native Hawaiian organizations to advise on the return, elimination of illegal commerce, and repatriation of tangible cultural heritage. The agencies and committees listed in paragraph (2) must provide information and assistance to the tribal working group convened under subsection (a) upon request. These include the Department of the Interior, Department of Justice, Department of Homeland Security, Department of State, Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Review Committee, and Cultural Property Advisory Committee. The curr_chunk states that any other relevant Federal agency can provide assistance under the Convention on Cultural Property Implementation Act.
